LaTeX Math

Math in LaTeX is very powerful and useful, asit produces very neat equations in a way that's known to anyone who has read a scientific paper, book or article.

Math code in LaTeX works out of the box so to speak, although several packages exist to facilitate writing certain things.

The code for writing math is best shown by an example:

In probability theory, a normal (or Gaussian or Gauss or Laplaceâ€“Gauss) distribution is a type of continuous probability distribution for a real-valued random variable. The general form of its probability density function is

$$ f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^{2}} $$

The code for the equation above is as follows:

\begin{equation*}
f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^{2}}
\end{equation*}

  • Omitting the * will give the equation a reference number
  • Greek symbols and letters are readily available
  • Math can also be written in-line by enclosing the expression in \( \) or $ $

LaTeX Math in HTML

  • Begin by inserting the appropiate script dependencies
  • Start writing LaTeX inside your html-document

LaTeX Figures

To include figures into your LaTeX-document, use the following syntax:

\begin{figure}[htpb]
\include[width=1\linewidth]{path-to-png}
\caption{Some caption}\label{fig:aritraryname}
\end{figure}

  • To center the figure (incase \linewidth is prepended with something $<1$) add \centering just after \begin{figure}[htpb]
  • Usually you should follow LaTeX placement attemps of the figure (somewhat controlled by [htpb]) but as a last resort you can try to force the figure to where you wish to have it by just having [h!].

LaTeX Languages

LaTeX is out of the box adapted for the English language. In order to have for example Swedish, some modifications are needed to the preamble:

  • \usepackage[T1]{fontenc}
  • \usepackage[utf8]{inputenc}
  • \usepackage[swedish]{babel}

At least this is what works for me. I also sometimes find it important to make sure that whatever .tex-file I'm writing in is encoded as UTF-8.

LaTeX Tables

My preferred what of writing tables now days is using longtable.

An example: 

            \begin{lontable}{l l}
            \caption{a table}\label{tab:mytbl} \\ \toprule
                \textbf{TH} & \textbf{TH} \\ \midrule
                \endfirsthead

                \texbf{TH} & \textbf{TH} \\ \bottomrule
                \endlastfoot

                \caption[]{-continuation-} \\ \toprule
                \textbf{TH} & \textbf{TH} \\ \midrule
                \endhead

                \multicolumn{2}{c}{-continues on next page-}\\ \bottomrule
                \endfoot

                some table content & some more table content \\ \midrule

            \end{longtable}
